results.title: [Tony Agapitos: First Greek Community Dance at Exhibition Centre 1961]
results.brief_description:
This film shows the first Greek Community Dance held at the Royal Exhibition Buildings, Melbourne in 1961.

The film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.brief_description:

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Arrival of the Greek Ship "Patris" at Victoria Dock 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows the arrival of the Greek ship ‘Patris’ to Victoria Dock in 1961 and her passengers coming to Australia to start a new life.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: 3ZZ Protest March]
results.brief_description:
‘Protest March, Melbourne’ (circa 1975-77) shows a protest march in Melbourne in the mid-1970s in support of multi-lingual community radio station 3ZZ, with crowds gathering at City Square then marching up Swanston Street.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: The Grannies
results.creator_credit: Marie Foulston, Luke Neher and Nick Murray
results.credit_line:
Visuals captured from Red Dead Redemption 2

Rockstar Games, USA, 2018

Courtesy Marie Foulston
results.brief_description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.
By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game world itself were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player becomes a set of artistic possibilities. Rather than focusing on the game’s objectives, their adventures beyond the map, and their reflections on them, are oriented around artistic inquiry, playfulness and friendship.
The unexpected terrain and landmarks the grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – – not because they help direct players towards a goal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marie Foulston, Luke Neher and Nick Murray
results.description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.

By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player piques curiosity about the materiality of the game’s environmental design. Textures collide at strange angles, revealing layers that are meant to be obscured. A strange grey cube hangs on the sky, monumental in its lack of finish and finesse compared to the landscape around it.

The unexpected terrain and landmarks The Grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – not because they help direct players towards a goal.

These artists’ explorations are not just a way to escape the game’s map, but to escape the game’s expectations of how a player should act, and its methods of anticipating their actions.
description_for_label:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.

By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player piques curiosity about the materiality of the game’s environmental design. Textures collide at strange angles, revealing layers that are meant to be obscured. A strange grey cube hangs on the sky, monumental in its lack of finish and finesse compared to the landscape around it.

The unexpected terrain and landmarks The Grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – not because they help direct players towards a goal.

These artists’ explorations are not just a way to escape the game’s map, but to escape the game’s expectations of how a player should act, and its methods of anticipating their actions.

Rockstar Games, USA, 2018

Courtesy Marie Foulston

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

results.title: Douglas Stewart
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Playwright and poet, Douglas Stewart, was for many years the Literary Editor of the Bulletin, and friend of many writers and artists, including Norman Lindsay, Judith Wright and David Campbell.

results.title: Alan Marshall
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A memorable discussion with an author of extraordinary spirit and charm, who is internationally known for his novel “I Can Jump Puddles”.

results.title: No more secrets
results.brief_description: Explores the issues of Child Abuse and provides strategies for both children and adults to enable them to deal with “secrets” which children often feel obliged to keep to themselves.

results.title: An Australian Summer
results.brief_description: A gentle comedy exploring, on a humorous and compassionate level, the shifting relationships within an Australian family over two decades, 1960-1980. The complexities of a family relationship where love as a binding force is tested by disappointment, are evocatively portrayed with a deft mixture of humour and poignancy.
